facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 18 of 1963 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 18 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 24, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 601 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 24, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 601 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Mudholkar, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mudholkar, J.

facts.text: Appellant tried for offence under s. 409 IPC by Mr. T. Bhattacharjee, Judge, Birbhum Special Court and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for four years.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried for an offence under s. 409, I.P.C. by Mr. T. Bhattacharjee, Judge, Birbhum Special Court and sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for four years.

facts.text: Conviction maintained in appeal by High Court but sentence reduced to rigorous imprisonment for two years.

anchor.surface_text: His conviction was maintained in appeal by the High Court but the sentence was reduced to rigorous imprisonment for two years.

facts.text: Appellant tried earlier by Mr. N. C. Ganguly, Judge, Birbhum Special Court and acquitted thereof on same facts and same offence.

anchor.surface_text: One of the points urged before the High Court was that upon the same facts and with respect to the same offence the appellant was tried earlier by Mr. N. C. Ganguly, Judge, Birbhum Special Court and acquitted thereof.

facts.text: Appellant was a shed clerk at Sainthia Railway Station.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was a shed clerk at Sainthia Railway Station

facts.text: Appellant alleged to have committed criminal breach of trust with respect to 8 bags of suji booked by rail at Murarai by Bhikam Chand Pipria, consignee firm of Lalchand Phusraj of Sainthia.

anchor.surface_text: is alleged to have committed criminal breach of trust with respect to 8 bags of suji which had been booked by rail at Murarai by one Bhikam Chand Pipria, the consignee being the firm of Lalchand Phusraj of Sainthia.

facts.text: Alleged to have done this in conspiracy with Ibrahim and Nepal Chandra Das.

anchor.surface_text: He was alleged to have done this in conspiracy with Ibrahim and Nepal Chandra Das.

facts.text: Charge sheet submitted against appellant under s. 409 IPC and two other persons by Officer-in-charge, Government Railway Police, Asansol.

anchor.surface_text: The offence was investigated into and a charge sheet was submitted against the appellant under s. 409, I.P.C. and two other persons by the Officer-in-charge, Government Railway Police, Asansol.

facts.text: Charge sheet filed by the Officer-in-charge himself in the court of Judge, Birbhum Special Court.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently he filed the charge sheet himself in the court of Judge, Birbbum Special Court.

facts.text: Case distributed to Birbhum Special Court for trial by notification No. 4515-J dated May 8, 1959, Law Judicial Department, Government of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: However, as set out in the order of Mr. Ganguly acquitting the appellant the case was distributed to the Birbhum Special Court for trial by notification No. 4515-J dated May 8, 1959  Law Judicial Department , Government of West Bengal.

facts.text: Prosecution examined 21 witnesses before Mr. Ganguly.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution examined 21 witnesses before him

facts.text: On August 28, 1959 Mr. Ganguly framed a charge against the appellant under s. 409, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: and on August 28, 1959 he framed a charge against the appellant under s. 409, I.P.C.

facts.text: Prosecution witnesses cross-examined on behalf of appellant and court examined him under s. 342 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution witnesses were cross-examined on behalf of the appellant and the court examined him under s. 342 of the Code.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor placed typed copy of High Court judgment in Criminal Appeal No. 377 of 1958 before Mr. Ganguly at arguments.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the hearing of arguments the Public Prosecutor placed before him a typed copy of a judgment of the High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 377 of 1958

facts.text: High Court in Cr App 377/1958 held Special Court cannot take cognizance on charge sheet due to amendment of s.5(1) WB Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Act 1949 by Act 27 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: in which it was held that a Special Court cannot, in view of the amendment of s. 5 1  of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment  Special Courts  Act, 1949 by Act 27 of 1956 take cognizance upon a charge sheet because it is neither entitled to follow the procedure for trial under s. 251-A nor can it take cognizance under s. 190 1  c

facts.text: Attention drawn to A.P. Misra v. The State where held that where magistrate could not legally take cognizance on charge sheet, proceedings without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The attention of the learned Judge was also drawn to A. P. Misra v. The State 1  where it was held that where a magistrate could not legally take cognizance of an offence on the basis of a charge sheet the entire proceedings before him are without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Mr. Ganguly acquitted appellant holding proceedings without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these decisions the learned Judge made an order of which the relevant portion runs thus So the proceeding is without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Formal complaint preferred by Public Prosecutor on May 16, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter a formal complaint was preferred by the Public Prosecutor on May 16, 1960

facts.text: Mr. Bhattacharjee succeeded Mr. Ganguly as Judge of Special Court, Birbhum.

anchor.surface_text: and Mr. Bhattacharjee who had succeeded Mr. Ganguly as Judge of the Special Court, Birbhum

facts.text: Mr. Bhattacharjee took cognizance of offence and commenced fresh proceeding against accused including appellant.

anchor.surface_text: took cognizance of the offence and commenced a fresh proceeding against all the accused persons, including the appellant.

facts.text: Mr. Bhattacharjee framed charge under s.409 IPC against appellant, convicted and sentenced him.

anchor.surface_text: He framed a charge under s. 409, I.P.C. against the appellant and eventually convicted and sentenced him with respect to it, as already stated,

facts.text: Appeal from conviction dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and the appeal from the conviction was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: The facts mentioned are not in dispute.

barred by the provisions of s. 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure hereinafter referred to as the Code .

concepts.interpretation: A person who has once been tried by a Court of competent jurisdiction for an offence and convicted or acquitted shall not be liable to be tried again for the same offence, nor on the same facts for any other offence for which a different charge might have been made under s.236 or convicted under s.237. Applies only if trial by competent court; nullity if no jurisdiction to take cognizance.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Code of Criminal Procedure a court can take cognizance of an offence only if the conditions requisite for initiation of proceedings before it as set out in Part B of Chapter XV are fulfilled. arguments.court_reasoning: s.494 assumes competently made charge and court competent to entertain withdrawal

arguments.claim: s.403 CrPC bars second trial only if first was by court of competent jurisdiction; lists requirements: tried by court, competent jurisdiction, acquitted

anchor.surface_text: From the language used in s. 403 1  of the Code it is clear that what can be successfully pleaded as a bar to a subsequent trial for the same offence or for an offence based on the same facts is that the accused had been  a  tried by a court,  b  of competent jurisdiction and  c  acquitted of the offence alleged to have been committed by him or an offence with which he might have been charged under s. 236 or for which he might have been convicted under s. 237, of the Code.

arguments.claim: Competence of court requires not just statutory entitlement to try category but also taking cognizance per CrPC Ch XV Part B conditions

anchor.surface_text: The competence of a court, however, depends not merely on the circumstance that under some law it is entitled to try a case falling in the particular category in which the offence alleged against the accused falls. In addition to this taking cognizance of the offence is also material in this regard.

arguments.claim: Auterfois acquit no application if accused not lawfully liable to be convicted at first trial due to lack of jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The defence of auterfois acquit, however, has no application where the accused person was not liable lawfully to be convicted at the first trial because the court lacked jurisdiction. This is what has been pointed out by the Court of Criminal Appeal in Thomas Ewart Flower v. R. 1 .

arguments.claim: Court taking cognizance only if CrPC Ch XV Part B conditions fulfilled; else no jurisdiction to try

anchor.surface_text: Under the Code of Criminal Procedure a court can take cognizance of an offence only if the conditions requisite for initiation of proceedings before it as set out in Part B of Chapter XV are fulfilled. If they are not fulfilled the court does not obtain jurisdiction to try the offence.

arguments.claim: Only court competent to initiate/carry proceedings can make valid acquittal barring subsequent trial

anchor.surface_text: It requires, however, no argument to say that only a court which is competent to initiate proceedings or to carry them on can properly make an order of acquittal, at any rate, an order of acquittal which will have the effect of barring a subsequent trial upon the same facts and for the same offence.

arguments.claim: Acquittal by court erroneously believing no jurisdiction to take cognizance is nullity; accused not in jeopardy

anchor.surface_text: Where a court comes to such a conclusion, albeit erroneously, it is difficult to appreciate how that court can absolve the person arraigned before it completely of the offence alleged against him. Where a person has done something which is made punishable by law he is liable to face a trial and this liability cannot come to an end merely because the court...

arguments.claim: Yusofally Mulla v. King: acquittal nullity if no jurisdiction (no valid sanction); no auterfois plea unless first trial lawful and could result in conviction
arguments.court_reasoning: Applies analogously where court opines no jurisdiction to take cognizance

arguments.claim: Witness examination etc. before incompetent court or court opining no jurisdiction not a 'trial' under s.403

anchor.surface_text: In addition to the competence of the court, s. 403 of the Code speaks of there having been a trial and the trial having ended in an acquittal. From what we have said above, it will be clear that the fact that all the witnesses for the prosecution as well as for the defence had been examined before Mr. Ganguly... cannot in law be deemed to be a trial at all.

arguments.claim: s.403 based on auterfois acquit and Art.20 Constitution: no double jeopardy unless first trial valid

anchor.surface_text: These provisions are based upon the general principle of auterfois acquit recognised by the English courts. The principle on which the right to plead auterfois acquit depends is that a man may not be put twice in jeopardy for the same offence. This principle has now been incorporated in Art. 20 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: Section 403 CrPC bars a subsequent trial only if the accused was previously tried by a court of competent jurisdiction and acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: From the language used in s. 403 1  of the Code it is clear that what can be successfully pleaded as a bar to a subsequent trial for the same offence or for an offence based on the same facts is that the accused had been  a  tried by a court,  b  of competent jurisdiction and  c  acquitted of the offence alleged to have been companymitted by him or an offence with which he might have been charged under s. 236 or for which he might have been companyvicted under s. 237, of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.403(1) requiring three elements: trial, competent jurisdiction, acquittal.

holdings.text: Competence of a court to try an offence requires not only statutory entitlement to the category but also proper taking of cognizance.

anchor.surface_text: The competence of a court, however, depends not merely on the circumstance that under some law it is entitled to try a case falling in the particular category in which the offence alleged against the accused falls. In addition to this taking cognizance of the offence is also material in this regard.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction analysis distinguishing general competence from procedural initiation via cognizance.

holdings.text: A court obtains jurisdiction to try only if cognizance taken after fulfilling CrPC Chapter XV Part B conditions.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Code of Criminal Procedure a court can take cognizance of an offence only if the conditions requisite for initiation of proceedings before it as set out in Part B of Chapter XV are fulfilled. If they are not fulfilled the court does not obtain jurisdiction to try the offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of CrPC procedural requirements for jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Only a court competent to initiate and carry proceedings can make a valid acquittal barring subsequent trial under s.403 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: It requires, however, no argument to say that only a court which is competent to initiate proceedings or to carry them on can properly make an order of acquittal, at any rate, an order of acquittal which will have the effect of barring a subsequent trial upon the same facts and for the same offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical necessity for barring effect under double jeopardy principle.

holdings.text: An acquittal by a court erroneously believing it lacks jurisdiction to take cognizance is a nullity; no power to acquit.

anchor.surface_text: Where, therefore, a court says, though erroneously, that it was not competent to take cognizance of the offence it has no power to acquit that person of the offence. An order of acquittal made by it is in fact a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court lacking self-perceived jurisdiction cannot validly terminate proceedings by acquittal; analogized to lack of sanction cases.

holdings.text: Proceedings before a court opining no jurisdiction, even with witness examination and s.342 statement, do not constitute a 'trial' under s.403 CrPC.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.403 requires actual competent trial; procedural steps insufficient without jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Framing of charge by incompetent court does not prevent fresh proceedings or invoke post-charge termination rules.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge validity depends on court's competence to cognizance.

holdings.text: s.494 CrPC withdrawal leading to acquittal assumes competent charge and court; inapplicable without jurisdiction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory assumption of competence not met.

holdings.text: Principle from Yusofally Mulla applies: no jeopardy if court opines no jurisdiction, even erroneously.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to invalid sanction cases where acquittal nullity; no lawful jeopardy.

holdings.text: Mr. Ganguly's acquittal order does not bar second trial under s.403 as nullity; conviction upheld.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application: no competent trial or valid acquittal; no s.403 bar.

anchor.surface_text: Public Prosecutor placed before him a typed copy of a judgment of the High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 377 of 1958 in which it was held that a Special Court cannot, in view of the amendment of s. 5 1  of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment  Special Courts  Act, 1949 by Act 27 of 1956 take cognizance upon a charge sheet because it is neither entitled to follow the procedure for trial under s. 251-A nor can it take cognizance under s. 190 1  c  unless in the latter case the provisions of s. 191 of the Code were complied with.

precedents.cited_proposition: a Special Court cannot take cognizance upon a charge sheet because it is neither entitled to follow the procedure for trial under s. 251-A nor can it take cognizance under s. 190(1)(c) unless s. 191 complied with

precedents.citation: A. P. Misra v. The State 1

anchor.surface_text: learned Judge was also drawn to A. P. Misra v. The State 1  where it was held that where a magistrate could not legally take cognizance of an offence on the basis of a charge sheet the entire proceedings before him are without jurisdiction. In view of these decisions the learned Judge made an order of which the relevant portion runs thus So the proceeding is without jurisdiction.

precedents.case_name: A P Misra v The State
precedents.cited_proposition: where a magistrate could not legally take cognizance of an offence on the basis of a charge sheet the entire proceedings before him are without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: the defence of auterfois acquit, however, has noapplication where the accused person was not liable lawfully to be convicted at the first trial because the court lacked jurisdiction. This is what has been pointed out by the Court of Criminal Appeal in Thomas Ewart Flower v. R. 1 . From the language used in s. 403 1  of the Code it is clear that what can be successfully pleaded as a bar to a subsequent trial for the same offence or for an offence based on the same facts is that the accused had been  a  tried by a Court,  b  of competent jurisdiction and  c  acquitted of the offence alleged to have been committed by him or an offence with which he might have been charged under s. 236 or for which he might have been convicted under s. 237.

precedents.cited_proposition: defence of autrefois acquit has no application where the accused was not liable to be lawfully convicted at the first trial because the court lacked jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Ajit Kumar Palit v. State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, according to him, the view taken by Mr. Ganguly that he could not have taken cognizance of the offence was erroneous as has been pointed out by this Court in Ajit Kumar Palit v. State of West Bengal 1  and, therefore, he could legally acquit the appellant. He further says that since Mr. Ganguly had not only framed a charge against the appellant but also examined all the witnesses both for the prosecution and for the defence and recorded the examination of the appellant he had completed the trial.

precedents.case_name: Ajit Kumar Palit v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Special Court could take cognizance of the offence contrary to earlier High Court view

precedents.citation: Yusofally Mulla Noorbhoy v. The King 2

anchor.surface_text: An order of acquittal made by it is in fact a nullity. In this connection we might profitably refer to the decision in Yusofally Mulla Noorbhoy v. The King 2 . That was a case where there was not 1  1963 1 Supp. S.C.R. 953. L.R. 76 I.A. 158. valid sanction as required by cl. 14 of the Hoarding and Profiteering Prevention Ordinance, 1943 for the prosecution of the appellant therein on separate charges of hoarding and profiteering.

precedents.case_name: Yusofally Mulla Noorbhoy v The King
precedents.cited_proposition: acquittal by a court lacking jurisdiction due to invalid sanction is a nullity and does not bar retrial; accused not in jeopardy
precedents.cited_holding: under the common law plea of autrefois acquit or convict can only be raised where the first trial was before a court competent to pass a valid order of acquittal or conviction

precedents.citation: Basdeo Agar walla v. King Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council accepted the view of the Federal Court in Basdeo Agar walla v. King Emperor 1  that the prosecution launched without valid sanction is invalid and held that under the common law plea of auterfois acquit or convict can only be raised where the  1  1945 F.C.R. 93. first trial was before a court competent to pass a valid order of acquittal or conviction. Unless the earlier trial was a lawful one which might have resulted in a conviction, the accused was never in jeopardy.

precedents.cited_proposition: prosecution launched without valid sanction is invalid

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: From the language used in s. 403 1  of the Code it is clear that what can be successfully pleaded as a bar to a subsequent trial for the same offence or for an offence based on the same facts is that the accused had been  a  tried by a court,  b  of competent jurisdiction and  c  acquitted of the offence alleged to have been companymitted by him or an offence with which he might have been charged under s. 236 or for which he might have been companyvicted under s. 237, of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Code of Criminal Procedure a court can take cognizance of an offence only if the conditions requisite for initiation of proceedings before it as set out in Part B of Chapter XV are fulfilled.
